Conditions.title: Conditions
Conditions.content:
Framework to Remember Medical Conditions (P-SOAP)
Patients Struggle on a problem

P ‚Äì Pathophysiology (What‚Äôs happening in the body?)
S ‚Äì Signs & Symptoms (What do you see/hear/feel?)
O ‚Äì Onset & Cause (When/how did it start?)
A ‚Äì Assessment & Diagnosis (Tests/findings to confirm)
P ‚Äì Plan & Treatment (What do you do about it?)






























Step of ConditionExplanationP - Pathophysiology(What‚Äôs happening in the body?)S - Signs and Symptoms(What do you see/hear/feel?)O - Onset and Cause(When/how did it start?)A - Assessment & Diagnosis(Tests/findings to confirm)P - Plan and Treatment(What do you do about it?)

Drugs/Adrenaline.title: Adrenaline
Drugs/Adrenaline.content:
SCOPE: EMT & AboveDrug: AdrenalineIndicationsBASICS SITS  Blood pressure support if unresponsive to metaraminol  Anaphylaxis  Severe asthma  Imminent respiratory arrest from COPD  Cardiac arrest  Severe bradycardia    Shock (septic, cardiogenic, neurogenic) unresponsive to sodium chloride IV and metaraminol IV  Intranasal for significant epistaxis  Topical for significant wound bleeding  Stridor causing severe respiratory distressContra-IndicationsNone!CautionsFAffectDosageSide effectsMATT VAN HATH  Myocardial Ischemia  Anxiety  Tachycardia  Tachydysrhythmia  Ventricular ectopy  And  Nausea / Vomiting  Hypertension  and  Tremors,  Hyperglycaemia
Phosphodiesterase Inhibitors
(These are typically medications with the suffix ‚Äúafil‚Äù, and commonly used for treatment of COPD, or erectile dysfunction). Examples: Viagra, Sildenafil,

Drugs/Aspirin.title: Aspirin
Drugs/Aspirin.content:
SCOPE: EMTDrug: Aspirin.IndicationsMC  M - Myocardial Ischemia  S - STEMIContra-IndicationsKSA - Known Severe allergy  Third Trimester of PregnancyCautionsKnown Bleeding Disorder Aspirin increases ‚Äúrisk‚Äù  Clinically significant bleeding.  Known worsening of bronchospasm with NSAIDS  , typically asthma or COPD, if clear history should be withheld.AffectAbsorbed in the liver, we administer aspirin because it has anti-platelet effects reducing the formation of clots in the blood, which helps keep blood vessels clear. (does have anti-pyretic, pain relief affects but low).RoutePO - per oralDosage300mg per oral for all adults.Side effectsIncreased bleeding.  Long term Administration - indigestion, gastrointestinal ulcerations or bleeding
Additional Information
The described doses are much higher than many references, however safe when not administered repeatedly.
Paracetamol is not indicated for pain associated with myocardial ischemia.
Paracetamol is not indicated for fever because the fever will reduce benefit if the patient has an infection. however can be given for discomfort caused by a fever IF the pt. has a temperature above 39C.
Use our aspirin over pt. provided medication as ours is not enteric coated - which delays the onset of effect.
If Unclear what pt. has taken, administer an additional 300mg.

Drugs/GTN---Glyceryl-Trinitrate-Spray.-(.title: GTN - Glyceryl Trinitrate Spray. (1)
Drugs/GTN---Glyceryl-Trinitrate-Spray.-(.content:
SCOPE: EMTDrug: GTN - Glyceryl Trinitrate Spray.IndicationsMCC  M -  myocardial ischemia  C - cardiogenic pulmonary oedema  C - control of hypertension during inter-hospital transfer for STEMI, or prior to fibrinolytic treatment for STEMIContra-IndicationsHASH-VT    H -  Heart rate below 40  A - Allergy  S - Systolic Below 110  H - Heart rate above 150  VT - Ventricular TachycardiaCautionsF-SADISM  F  - frail  S -  shock  A  - atrial stenosis  D -  dysrhythmia  I  - Inhibitor‚Äôs of Phosphodiesterase. see comment below  S - STEMI  M -  Mitral StenosisAffectHow does GTN work?  GTN works on the smooth muscles of the blood vessels, dilating the Veins and arteries.  - in Cardiogenic pulmonary oedema (CPO) this reduces the pressure of the arteries going to the lungs and veins coming back, this reduces the ‚Äúleaking‚Äù of fluid from the vessels into the lung‚Äôs, and theRouteSublingualDosageThink MCC (0.4, 0.8, 0.4-8)      in correspondence with the indications:  Myocardial Ischemia - 0.4mg or one spray every 3 - 5 minutes  CPO - 0.8mg every 3-5 mins  Control of hypertension w/STEMI - 0,4-0,8 mg every 3-5 minutes. When using GTN for the treatment of hypertension with STEMI we would be relying on a paramedic or calling Clinical desk for Support.Side effectsHALF-T  H  - Hypotension    And  L  Light headedness  F  - Flushing  T -  Tachycardia
Phosphodiesterase Inhibitors
(These are typically medications with the suffix ‚Äúafil‚Äù, and commonly used for treatment of COPD, or erectile dysfunction). Examples: Viagra, Sildenafil,

Drugs/Ibuprofen.title: Ibuprofen
Drugs/Ibuprofen.content: SCOPE: FRDrug: Ibuprofen.IndicationsPain ReliefContra-IndicationsKSA  Third Trimester of Pregnancy  Administered within the last 4 hours.CautionsTRACKPADS -  T -  taking warfarin  R -  Renal Impairment - may worsen  A  - Abdominal Pain, particularly if the pt is unwell or vomiting  C -  Clinically Significant Bleeding  K -  Known Worsening of Bronchospasm with NSAIDS (perhaps Asthma, COPD)  P -  Pregnancy, associated with premature delivery.  A -  Age greater than 75 yrs, particulalry in illness, infection, dehydration - renal imp.  D -  Dehydration or Shock.  S -  Known bleeding disorderAffectRouteDosageSide effects

Drugs/Ondansetron-IM.title: Ondansetron IM
Drugs/Ondansetron-IM.content:
SCOPE: EMTDrug: Ondansetron.IndicationsClinically significant vomiting and / or nausea.Contra-IndicationsKAS -  K -  known allergy  A -  Age less than one year  S  - Suspected serotonin syndromeCautionsnoneAffectRoutePODosage4mg IM for an adult;  remember this because some ampoules are different sizes    see pedriatic drug doses for a child.Side effectsHeadache and Flushing
Suspected Serotonin Syndrome:
Serotonin Syndrome is a serious drug reaction, where medications build up high levels of serotonin in the body. Serotonin is needed for the nerves and brain to function, but too much can cause signs and symptoms such as:

Shivering
Diarrhea
Agitation
Dilated pupils
Rapid HR, High BP

Severe Serotonin Syndrome:

High fever
Tremors
Seizures
Irregular Heartbeat
Unconscious

Drugs/Paracetamol.title: Paracetamol
Drugs/Paracetamol.content:
SCOPE: FRDrug: Paracetamol.Indicationsmild to moderate pain, or above in addition to other medicationsContra-IndicationsAcronym: ATAK  A - Known Allergy!CautionsT - Taken within 4 hrs.  A - Abdominal Pain.  particularly if pt is very unwell or vomiting. If a pt. is very unwell or vomiting, the possibility of significant intra-abdominal pathology exists and should be withheld.  K - Known Severe liver disease. Liver Disease must be severely impaired before paracetamol clearance is altered, but the balance is in favor of withholding paracetamol in this setting.AffectMetabolized in the Liver!RoutePO - Per OralDosageAdult:  1.5mg for an adult weighing above 80 kgs (3 Tablets).  1 g PO for an adult weighing 80 kgs or less. (2 tablets)  It is expected to consult the drug tables for a child.Side effectsNo common adverse affects.  Usual onset: 30 -60 Minutes,  Duration 4 - 6 hrs.
Additional Information
The described doses are much higher than many references, however safe when not administered repeatedly.
Paracetamol is not indicated for pain associated with myocardial ischemia.
Paracetamol is not indicated for fever because the fever will reduce benefit if the patient has an infection. however can be given for discomfort caused by a fever IF the pt. has a temperature above 39C.

Mnemonics-and-Tools/Secondary-Survey-Mne.title: Secondary Survey Mnemonic
Mnemonics-and-Tools/Secondary-Survey-Mne.content:
Here‚Äôs a revised mnemonic that groups similar actions together, making it easier to remember:
CHANCE-BEAMS
==C - C==onsent: Gain informed consent before the assessment.
==H - H==ead, Neck, and Face:

L - Look and feel for deformity, tenderness, bleeding, or infection.
J - Jugular veins Distention
M - Medical information adjunct:
C - Cervical spine: Examine if appropriate.

==A - A==irway and Chest:


S - Symmetry of air entry: Look and feel.


C - Crepitus and tenderness: Look and feel.


M - Movement of the chest wall: Look.


R - Respiratory distress signs: Look.


L - Listen for air entry and added sounds.


==N - N==ervous System:

G - Glasgow Coma Scale: Record and assess.
P - Pupils: Examine for asymmetry and reaction to light.
M - Movement: Check face and limbs for normal movement.
S - Sensation: Test soft touch on all four limbs.
W - Walk, Memory, Balance, Coordination: Assess if appropriate.

==C - C==irculation:

W - Wounds and fractures: Look and feel.
I - Infection signs or edema: Look and feel.
C - Color and warmth: Look and feel.
C - Capillary refill: Re-examine.
M - Medical information adjunct: Look for bracelets or other indicators.

==E - E==xamine Abdomen


M - Masses, distension, tenderness: Look and feel.


P - Pelvis: Look and feel for tenderness.


BEAMS: Back, Examine Pelvis, Masses, Spine.
Back:
Examine the
Abdomen:
Masses?
Spine:
Cervical Clearance
B - Back and Spine:

T - Tenderness or deformity: Look and feel.
S - Sacral edema: Look and feel.

Mnemonic: CHANCE-BEAMS
CHANCE: Consent, Head, Airway, Nervous system, Circulation, Examine.
BEAMS: Back, Examine Abdomen, Masses, Spine.

Module-1.title: Module 1
Module-1.content:
Reminders

LMA is always preferred over NPA /OPA eveny when secondary to drowning

however more likely to not be a good fit and be removed in drowning


if having trouble with LMA use 2 persons on airway first.
Drowning - what does prioritizing airways mean?

Not flufing around with drugs etc



Three points of lung:


Inflammation


Mucus Plugging


Bronchospasms of the airways.


Cardiac Notes
Shock

Module-1/Cardiac-Notes.title: Cardiac Notes
Module-1/Cardiac-Notes.content:
Review Questions


PCI (Percutaneous Coronary Intervention) Helps:
Splint Open the Coronary Arterys (Stenting)


What is Angina?
Angina is chest pain or pressure caused by a lack of adequate bllod flow to the myocardium


What are the types of Angina?
Three Types:


Unstable Angina - defined as angina that is irregular, worsens, changes or comes on at rest.


Stable Angina - narrowing of the coronary arteries (typically due to plaque) causes myocardial ischemia on exertion when oxygen demands are increased.


Prinzmental Angina - often occurs at rest, very painful - -spasming of the coronary arteries.




Is Pericarditis caused by virus or bacteria?
BOTH


The Main Stages of Plaque Buildup are:
fatty streak ‚Äî> , fibrous fatty plaque, ‚Äî> Advanced Plaque Buildup


what is ACS - Acute Coronary Syndrome?
ACS is defined as a reduction or complete occlusion of blood flow in the coronary arteries.


What does ACS encompass?
Angina, NSTEMI, and STEMI


How does musculoskeletal chest pain differ from the pain experienced during an MI?
Musculoskeletal pain is localised


What are the three non-modifiable cardiac risk factors?
family History, gender, age


Failure of the left ventricle typically results in..
Fluid backup in the lungs.


How do ACE inhibitors help in heart failure?
By relaxing the blood vessels


Indigestion type pain is a sign of‚Ä¶
Myocardial Ischemia


Patients with heart failure may struggle to breath in what position? Why?
Pts may struggle to breathe more if they are lying flat on the bed.
This is because as fluid backup into the lungs from the left ventricle in heart failure, this fluid will cover more surface area of the lungs as they are lying down, making it difficult to breathe.


What is heard on auscultation of heart failure?
Crackles, typically in both sides


Does a 86 yr old female with initial PEA have a good prognosis?


The myocardium is the..


What is the role of each ventricle and aorta in the heart?


If John took cocaine 12 minutes ago, what type of angina is he most likely experiencing?


What are examples of severe co-morbidities?


Differential Diagnoses
Musculoskeletal Chest Pain
commonly caused by trauma around the rib cage or muscle strains.
LOW threshold for suspection of myocardial ischemia


                  
                  Signs and symptoms: 
                  
                


Localised pain, esp on palpation.
Pain during Movement or taking deep breaths



Pericarditis
viral OR bacterial infection of the pericardium. things to help identify potential
pericarditis are:


                  
                   Fever , SOB, Palpitations, Weakness, Pain decreased on sitting up.
                  
                

Pulmonary embolism
a PE is a blood clot lodging in the pulmonary blood vessels, typically from the legs. (DVT)
Typical signs and symptoms:


                  
                   SOB , Pleuritic Chest pain, Decreased O2, Tachycardic, Hypotension ?Haemoptysis
                  
                

Pneumonia
is a chest infection in the lungs that can affect all age groups, most commonly young and elders. caused by Virus OR Bacteria


                  
                   Fever, Tachypnoea, Localised / Sharp chest pain, tachycardia, SOB
                  
                

HyperVentilation Syndrome
occurs when the patient over ventilates, causing a rapid drop in Carbon dioxide is needed in the body. (RR 20 typically)
may be caused by Mental Health ‚Äî< Asthma, Pnuemonia, COPD, Diabetic Ketoacidosis, Myocardial Infarction, Shock
Trauma
any injury to the chest can obviously cause chest pain, and if you are stuggling ask.
any significant chest pain needs transportation for a chest ray and improvement.
Congestive Heart Failure
the heart cannot pump weel enough to meet the bodys needs. can be caused by several conditions.. commonly MI or hypertension


                  
                  Signs and symptoms: 
                  
                


Crackles on Auscultation SOB thats worse on exertion
Orthopnoea Coughing up pink, foamy mucus
Tachycardia Tired / lethargic
Pedal / ankle oedema Swelling of the abdomen (ascites).



Why do we always transport significant chest pain?
Lead Recognition
Why do we moved to a lead V4R Placement?
leads 1 111, 1AVF, ST Elevation is indicative of STEMI
AFter V4R Placement, if there is still ST Elevation in the V4 lead, it indicates right ventricle involvement - which means GTN is a bad idea - Gtn will drop the blood pressure that the right ventricle needs to keep pumping.
Posterior lead Placement
WHen? when you see elevation in the frontal leads - look for depression in the posterior leads
and Why?


                  
                  V4 becomes V7 , V5 becomes V8, V^ becomes V9 - 
                  
                

ECG Paper Translation

A Fib has no p waves

HyperKaleamia -
we can nebulise salbutamol for ipatropium?


pericarditis - p wave dips into the start of the qrs wave


what do you call a normal sinus ecg with varied pace?

sinus ahhrythmia



J point - curve back to horizontal after s - used to measure how big the st elevation is


PEA
READ ON VAlsavla !!!


5 Step Method

























Rythnmcount number of r waves on a 5 second strip and multiply by ten
Cardiac Assesment
HIPPA PV
HX
previous medical history?
medications?
betablockers? olol,
blood thinners? (warfarin, dabigatran colpidogrel, statins)?
Last medical contact? Family history? ? Hyperlipidemia











Symptoms? what causes vomiting?  Syncopy? while sitting?  Fatigue on exertion?  Diaphoresis? (Sweating)  llight headendess? exertion?  ?fatigue .. ?tired  Orthopnea? (Difficulty on lying down, easier to stand up ()  SOB | Dyspnoea ?
DISCOURAGED: taking vitals while talking unless urgent - distracting the patient
DAN -
Status 1‚Äôs ALWAYS require ICP attendance,
Status 2‚Äôs ALWAYS require Paramedic attendance


                  
                  Chest pain, SOB , Dizyness, nausea, vomiting, 
                  
                

Inspection

Expose the chest , maintaining modesty if needed)
Check for scarring , ask for previous surgerys
Pacemaker?
? Lung Sounds? (Cardiogenic Pulmnoray Odemea, ‚Ä¶)
Any pulsating masses ?

AAA

‚Äútearing pain into the back‚Äù









JVD - Jugular Vein Distention?
Is there Ascites on the abdomen? Fluid around the abdomen ? (portal vein)



                  
                  Aortic Rupture: 
                  
                


The vessel of the Aorta gets blood trapped inside it, slowly enlargening the aortic vessel.
This can often dilate up to 10cm. When rupturing extermely high chance of death
MAss would be just under the ribs.



Pulses

Feel the radial pulse

Pace? Regular? Strong / Weak? Check both sides for comparusib


Brachial Pulses on children
Femoral Pulses in Cardiac Arrest

Palpation
palpate the chest wall
pain on palpation?
Auscultation
Listen for a Lub-Dub , regular sound

Listening for intricate sounds not covered in this course, own time

Places to auscultate:

2nd intercostal space - aortic valce and pulmonary valve.
4th / 5th intercistal space - triscupid valve
5th intercostal space - Mid clavicular line - Mitral / Biscupid valve

Peripherals

swelling? Oedema? Pedal Oedema - is it pitting? How far up?
Sacral Oedema ? (in the lower back)
Limb baselines?

CRT Colour? Warmth? Sensation? Movement?



Vitals
Blood pressure ? Postural Changes?
12 Lead ECG
The Rest of them
ACS Signs and Symptoms













diaphoresis (profuse sweating)  ‚Äì pallor  ‚Äì hypotension  ‚Äì nausea  ‚Äì vomiting  ‚Äì irregular heart rate  ‚Äì shortness of breath  ‚Äì tired or lethargic  ‚Äì sense of impending doom.

Module-1/Shock.title: Shock
Module-1/Shock.content:
What is Shock?
Global Hypoperfusion at the cellular level.
Types of Shock
HAS SHOC
H - Hypovolemic Shock
los of significant fluid
A - Anaphylactic Shock
S - Septic Shock
localised infection gets into the bloodstream


                  
                  - Low BP - Dilated Blood vessels help white blood cells fight infections 
                  
                

Distributive Shock
covers sepsis, anapyhlatic, neurgenic shock covers shock where the fuild is not lost from the body but is in the wrong
Spinal / Neurogenic Shock
There is an injury to the spine that causes neurogenic shock
H - Hypo Adrenal Shock
specific to the population with known illness. the body cant manage raised cortisol levels
O - Obstructive Shock
The Heart or it‚Äôs blood vessels is restricted by an obstruction, such as tension pneumorthorax.
C - Cardiogenic Shock
Shock caused by the heart, eg M. Infarction
RAAS
What does RAAS Do? RAAS are the systems used to increase blood pressure.
Angiotensin (2) - increases the amount of salt
Signs in Stages of Shock

























































































VitalsCompensatingDe CompensatingIrreversibleHRIncreasedBpNo ChangeRRSkinLOC / GCSCRTSpo2TemperatureStatusStatus 3Status 2Status 1IF GCS under 9, status 1MI / Status 1A tourniquet is trimmed. status 2, time critical
Types of Shock: HAS SHOC
Hypovolemic Shock
Anaphylactic
Septic
Spinal / Neurogenic Shock
Hypo-Adrenal Shock
Obstructive Shock
Cardiogenic Shock

Module-2.title: Module 2
Module-2.content:
Pharmacology
Human Factors
Diabetes and The Endocrine System

Module-2/Diabetes-and-The-Endocrine-Syst.title: Diabetes and The Endocrine System
Module-2/Diabetes-and-The-Endocrine-Syst.content:
Covers:

Endocrine Glands Of the Body
Diabietes Mellitus
Acute Complications of Diabetes Mellitus
Chronic Complications of Diabetes Meliitus



                  
                  Important
                  
                


The Endocrine System
The endocrine system uses hormones to control other parts of the body.
Hormones travel through the Body via the bloodstream to distant targets, where they exert their effect. Hormones Reulate most body systems including Growth, Reproduciton, and Metabolism.



Endocrine Glands Of the Body

















































GlandAction of HormonesHypothalamusThe Hipothalamus maintains homestasis - the bodys internal balance.Pineal GlandRegulats sleep patternsPituitary GlandStimulates growth and regulates activity of the other endocrine glandsThyroid GlandThe thyroid gland Helps to regulate MetabolismParathroid GlandsThe parathyroid glands help regulate potassium levelsAdrenal GlandsIncrease Blood glucose level and Heart RatePancreasRegulates blood glucose levelOvariesPromote development of female sex characteristicsTestsPromote development of male sex characteristicsThymusStimulates the development of disease fighting T-cells
Endocrine Glands Of the Body
The Hypothalamus
The Hypothalamus is a small, almond sized part of the brain, located above (anterior to) the brain stem and below (superior to) the thalamus.
The hypothalamus integrates the activities of both the nervous and endocrine systems by:


Maintaining Homestasis by stimulating or ionhibiting key processes, such as heart rate, blood pressure, hunger, thirst, and body temperature


Controlling the pituitary gland


Synthesising two important hormones,

The Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)
and OxyToxin

Which are then release into the bloodstream by the posterior pituitary gland


The Pituitary Gland
The pituitary gland is a small, pea sized part of the brain, located below the hypothalamus.
It is known as the ‚Äòmaster gland‚Äô as it regulates most of the endocrine gland sin the body. It has two lobes, the anterior and posterior, which haver very different functions


The Pituitary Gland releases Nine hormones into the blood stream for circulation. one of these is the antidurietic hormone, ADH.
ADH is released in response to a fall in blood pressure or blood volume, such as is seen in hypovolaemic shock. It Works by reducing the amount of water from being excreted at the kidneys which will increase blood volume, and by causing peripheral vasoconstriction which increase blood pressure.
graph TD
G[Decreased blood pressure] --> A
H[Decreased blood volume] --> A

  A[Hypothalamus]--> f[Posterior Pituitary] -->B[Anti-diuretic hormone ADH]--> C[Blood vessels \n- constriction]-- Increased systemic \nvascular resistance --> E[Increased Arterial Pressure]
  B --> D[Kidneys \n - fluid reabsorption] -- Increased blood volume--> E



The Adrenal Glands
The Adrenal glands are small structures attached to the top of each kidney.
Each gland is divided into two parts: the Adrenal cortex and the adrenal medulla, and each part has seperate endocrine functions.


The Adrenal Cortex
The adrenal cortex produces several steroid hormones, known as corticosteroids.
The two main hormones produced by the adrenal cortez are aldosterone and cortisol.

Aldesterone Helps to regulate the blood pressure by maintaining the body‚Äôs salt and water levels. It plays an important role in the body‚Äôs response to shock. Without aldosterone, the body would become severly dehydrated.
Cortisol
is also known as a hydrocortisone, and the ‚Äòstress‚Äô hormone. It is involved in the flight or fight response, helps to regulate metabolism, and has anti-aging properties.



The Adrenal Medulla
produces hormones known as catecholamines.
Adrenaline and noradrenaline are both produced by the adrenal medulla.
Although released at a slow rate continously, the rate of release is dramatically increased with sympathetic nervous system stimulation.
These two hormones are responsible for the phyioslogical signs of the stress response such as tachycardia, increased blood pressure, tachypnoea, and pale, cool, sweaty skin.
HypoAdrenal Shock
A complication we occasionally see is hypoadrenal shock, or adrenal crisis, sometimes known as Addisonian‚Äôs crisis. It is cause by inadequate levels of circulating cortisol. Some clinical conditions may result in abnormal adrenal function and low levels of cortisol producion. For these patients, the body is unable to release additional cortisol when a stress response is required,
This places these patients at risk of Hypoadreanl Shock.
they will offten have extra medication at home and instructions on when to take this. Personnel are encourage to folow these instructions and to call clinical desk (0800 111 help) for further advice).


The Thyroid gland
located just in front of the trachea, below the thyroid cartilae, the maiun function of the thyroid gland is to regulate metabolism.
Thyroid disdynctuin is relatively common in NZ. the two main conditions seen are hyper thyroidism and hypothyroidism.
The Pancreas
The pancreas is approximaately 15-25cm in length and rests just inder the stomach in the epigastrum of the abdominal cavity.
Approximately 98% of the pancreas is composed of exocrine cells whic secrete enzymes to break down proteins, fat, and carbohydrates in food. The remaining 2% of the pancreas is composed of endocrine cells. These are clusters of cels called pancreatic islets, aslo known as the islets of Langerhan‚Äôs. These endocrine cels secrete hormones directly into nearbyblood vessels for systemic distribtuion, including glucagon and insulin
HypoThyroidism
often treatted with a medication called thyroxine,
HyperThyroidism
treatment options include medication and surgical options.


                  
                   Neither
                  
                


of these thyroid conditions are directly treatable in our out of hospital setting, although it may be necessary to treat resulting symptoms which occur as a result.



Gland
The
Diabietes Mellitus
Acute Complications of Diabetes Mellitus
Chronic Complications of Diabetes Meliitus
Review Questions


What are parts of the endocrine System?
The endocrine system includes the:

Hypothalamus
Pituitary gland
Adrenal Glands
Thyroid Gland
Pancreas
The pineal gland
thymus
testes or ovaries
HPATPTTT



What Conditions can affect the endocrine System?

Module-2/Human-Factors.title: Human Factors
Module-2/Human-Factors.content:
What does this paper aim to achieve? 
                  
                


This paper aims to get you to focus on and remember 5 Principles that help you effective manage yourself and crew members.



The 5 principles outlined , in DETAIL, are:


Call For Help when Required. (and how)


Establish Team Leader‚Äôs.


Assess Appropriate Resource Use.


Step Back and ReAssess.


5 Principles to remember
Call for Help When Required
Establish a Team Leader.
Appropiate Resource Use
Step Back And Re Assess
Effective Communication
Review Questions

What are the 5 principles for good crew and resource management?

Module-2/Pharmacology.title: Pharmacology
Module-2/Pharmacology.content:
What is Pharmacology?
Pharmacology is the study of how medicines interact with other molecules in the body and how they affect the body. Pharmacology can be divided into two:
Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacodynamics.
Terms To Learn

























































Adverse Affectan adverse effect, also known as a sifde effect, is an undesired result caused by the administration of a medicine. Not all patients will experience adverse effects and when we want to consider administering a medication we need to consider is possible adverse affects are worth achieving the desired result of the medicine.BioAvailabilityBioavailability is the percentage of a medication that reaches the systemic circulation umetabolised for the body to use therapeutically. Medications given Intravaneously have a much higher bio-availability than those given orally. This is due to first-pass metabolism.Duration of effectThe length / amount of time a medication remains above the minimum concentration levels.  (eg, Ondansetron duration of effect is 4 - 8 hrs).Half - lifeis the time take for the plasma concentration to fall by one half. Medicines with short half lives leave the body quickly, whereas medicines with long half-lives leave the body slowly.InteractionInteraction can occur when the interaction of one medication alters the clinical effects of another. This may result in an increase or decrease in either beneficial or harmful effects of either Medication.Mechanism of ActionDescribes how the medication has it‚Äôs effect.  For example, Ondansetron, an antiemetic, blocks (antagonizes) serotonin receptors centrally in the brain and perpherally in the GI Tract, resulting in a reduction in nausea and vomiting.(MEC): Minimum Effective Concentration(MEC) the lowest concentration of the medicine required to achieve the therapeutic benefit.(MTC) Maximum Therapeutic ConcentrationIs the concentration at which a medicine produces unwanted adverse effects. It is also known as a minimum toxic concentration.Onset of Effectthe length of time it takes for a medicine to become effective - and it is dependent on the route of administration.Peak ConcentrationPeak concentration refers to peak plasma levels and is the highest level of medicine concentration in the blood. For example, pleak plasma concentration of Ondansetron following a 4mg intramuscular dose is attained after approximately 4 minutes.PharmacoKineticsIs what the body does to the medicine, and the is concerned with the MOI, where and how a medicine asserts its affects, and the associated body‚Äôs pharmalogical response.PharmacodynamicsIs what the medicine does to the body. Pharmacodynamics is concerned with how medicines enter the body and their movement through it until eliminated.
Expanding on our Terms Above
Multiple Dosing, Why?
we dose multiple times to maintain a steady concentration of a medication to maintain optimum effectiveness, such as pain relief. for epilepsy, or chronic diseases.
After the administration of a single dose, the medication concentration in the plasma rises above and then falls below the MEC - Minimum effective concentration, resulting in a decline in therapeutic effort. Multiple Doses are used to maintain a steady concentration of the medication, to achieve optimum affectiveness.
Maximum Therapeutic Concentration.
Maximum therapeutic concentraition, also known as the minimum toxic concentration, is the concentration at which a medication starts producing unwanted adverse effects.
Medicines with a short half-life leave the body quickly whereas medicines with long half-lives leave the body slowly.
Onset Of Effect
Onset Of Effect: the length of time it takes for a medication to have effects on the body, and is dependent on the route of administration.
Pharmacodynamics vs
is What medicine does to the body. It is concerned with the mechanism of action - where and how a medicine exerts its affects on the body, and the subequent body‚Äôs pharmlogical response.
what medicine does to the body, and how they do it
Pharmacokinetics
Is what the body does to the medicine. Pharmacoknetics is concerned with how medicines enter the body and their movement through the body until eliminated.
what the body does to the medicine
it includes (A,B,C,D) - administration, bioavailability, clearance, and distribution
üí° Why is pharmacokinetics important?
By understanding pharmacokinetic principles, medicine therapy can be maximised to enhance benefits and Hamrm, through informed decisions.
Factors affecting pharmacokinetics

Age: An elder person may have slower G.I Activity, and this can increase absorption
Physiological Alterations to the body, such as increased adipose (fat) tissue, can affect distribution, and clearance of medicine of the body.
Disease processes which affect liver and kidney functions - the organs of medicine elimination - are responsible for large variances in pharmacokinetics.
Diminished vascular perfusion of one or more parts of the body is encountered in conditions such as cardiac failure. This diminished perfusion can affect the different pharmacokinetic mechanisms:

perfusion of the absorption site influence absorption
variation of the liver and kidneys affects the metabolism and excretion of the medication
variation of body perfusion may alter distribution to certain organs.


Body Size may alse affect liver and kidney function,, with obesity believed to increase clearance of medicines.

Routes Of Administration - Parental Vs Enteral
Parental Routes - bypass the GI Tract.













































Example of Medication givenTime for RouteIntravenousIntraosseous (into a bone)IntramuscularSubcutaneous  (under the skin)Inhalation or NebulisedTopical  (local to site required)Intranasal
Enteral routes - absorption through the G.I Tract



































Example of Medication givenTime for RoutePer OralOrogastic / nasogastric  via a tube inserted into the stimach via the mouth or nose.Per Rectum  into the rectumBuccal  (between gum and cheek)Sublingual  (under the tongue)
The life-cycle of medicines in the body
Absorption
The passage of medicine from the site of administration into the bloodstream.For example, a medication adminstered per Oral (PO) is absorbed from the stomach and / or intestine into the portal (liver) circulation, and a medicine that is administered intramuscularly (IM) is absorbed from the muscle into the systemic circulation. Absorption occurs by active or passive transport.
The bodys environment into which the medicine is administered, along with the chemical composition of the medicine, work together to determine the rate and extent of medicine absorption. The rate of abosrption determins how soon the medicine will produce its effects and the amount of medicine absorption determines how intense the effects are.
Factors influencing BioAvailibility
Blood Flow
The more blood flow to the tissue at the absorption site, the faster the medication is absorbed. Fir example, When a patient is shocked, The blood flow to the GastroIntestinal Tract is reduced, and therefore Oral Medication would be less effective. However, Absorption is not Required when a medicine is administered intravenously, as the medication directly enters the bloodstream
graph TD
  A[Pt is in Shock,\n Less blood flow]
  A -- less blood flow to GI Tract.--> B
  A -- Normal access Intravenously --> C
  B[Oral Medications Not as Effective]
  C[Intravenous Medications Still Work The Same]

Surface Area for Absorption
The larger the surface area, the faster the absorption. For Example, a Patient who has had a section of their bowel surgically removed due to Chron‚Äôs Disease would have a slower rate of absorption than a Pt with an intact bowel due to decrease surface area.
Shown Above: Villi, the finger line projections within the GI Tract that increase the surface area availble for absorption.
Lipid Water Solubility
Because Cell Membranes are lipiod (fat), The greater the lipid-solubility of a medication, The Faster the absorption.
It is also easier for smaller molecules to penetrate and be absorbed by cell membranes than larger molecules.
PH of Medications
Most medications are either weak acids or weak bases. An Acid Medium is absorbed more easily in na acidic environment and vis versa, and Medium Alkaline medication is absorbed more easily in Alkaline Environments. For Example, Aspirin (Acetylsalicylic acid) is an acid based medication that abosrbs well in the stomach.
Summary:

Blood Flow to the Area
Surface Area available for Absorption
Lipid-Solubility of the medicine
PH of the medicine and the PH of the bosys‚Äôs internal environment
Medicine Concentration
Structures that the medication needs to pass through.

Distribution of Medication
Distribution of Medication
the moement of medications throughout the body, and occurs after absorption. Distribution is determined by Three Factors:

Blood FLow to the tissues.
The ability of medicine to exit the circulatory system.
The ability of the medication to enter cells, if required.

A Medications Ability to Exit the circulatory System
After a medication has been delivered to the target tissue, the next step is to exit the circulatory system to produce the desired effect.
Most medications do not evoke their effects within the blood, therefore the ability for the medication to be able to exit the circulatory system (the blood) is important.

Lipid Soluble Medications have a high affinity for adipose (fat) tissue, but adipose tissue has a low blood flow therefore prolonging the time the medication remains in the body.

Capillary Beds make up a single layer of epithelial Cells, which enable medication molecules to move easky and quickly pass through to the interstitial space and then into target cells.
Many medicines are bound to proeteins within the body. Medicines can be bound to plasma proteins as well as tissue proteins. The degree of meidine to protein binding often effects the efficiency of the medication. Plasma protein binfing can have mulptiple effects on the pharmacokinetics of a medication. The binding of medication to plasma proteins is the main determinant of a medicaions disposition. When a medication is bound to plasma proteins it is not activel distributed to the site of action. Furthermore, the bound medication remains in the blood, while the unbound (free) portions may be metabolised or eliminated.
Only Free or Unbound Medicines can intereact with receptors. therefore only free medicine molecules can produce our therapeutic affect.
Example: Warfarin is a highly protein bound medicine that must unbind from proteins to leave the blood. If a patient who takes Warfarin experiences a change in protein level, as a result of liver cirrhosis or malnutrition, the warfarin dose must be adjusted to take this into account.
Ability of Medicine to enter the Cells
Some medications must enter the cell to reach their site of action and most medicines must enter cells to undergo metabolism and elimination. This is affected by a transport system being in place and the lipid solubility of the medication.
Passing The Blood Brain Barrier..
Only very lipid (dar?? can enter the brain
Metabolism
What is metabolism?
Metabolism involves enzymes. Most medications undergo chemical modification to create compounds, known as metabolites, that are easily eliminated from the body. Metabolites may be more or less active than the original medicne, and they can make the medicine more water-soluble to facilitate elimination. These chemical modifications occur primarily in the liver.
First Pass Effect
The First Pass effect is a process in which the liver can partially or completely inactivate a medication before it reaches the systemic circulation. For medicines adminstered Orally, Absorbe from the GI tract, and transported to the liver, Via the Hepatic Portal Vein, this may result in none or only a small portion of the active medicaiton reaching the systemic cicrulation and the intended target tissue or organ. This process can be protective, as it enables the liver to in-activate medications that are potentially harmful before they are distributed throughout the body.
If it is a medicaiton that requires a therapeutic affect, Then this process can be bypassed by administering the medication parentarally.
Factors Influencing Metabolism
Age
In infancy, the liver is not fully developed, therefore the ability to metabolize is limited. INfants up to one yea if age are sensitive to some medicines.
Nutrition
Medicines metabolized by the liver require many cofactors to be able to metabolise effectively. If a patient is malnourished, these co-factors may be deficient, and metabolism will be compromised.
Competition between Medications

When tow medicines are metabolised by the same metabolic pathway, they tend to compet. This decrease the rate at which one or both medicines are being metaboliszed and can lead do medicine accumulation.
For example, alcohol metabolism uses up a key component in the metabolism of paracetamol If too much alchohol has been ingested too close to paracetamol administration, paracetamol cannot be broken down via its normal mechanism. This can lead to toxic damage witihn the liver.

Elimination
Elimination is the removal of medicine from the body. All medicines are eventually Elimanated. Medicines may be eliminated in the unchanged form or after being metabolised and effectively changed. They can be eleciminated in urine, bile, exhaled air, saliva, sweat, breast mil, or faeces. Most water-soluble medicines and their metabolites are eliminated by the kidneys in urine.

Saliva - Exhaled Air - Breast Milk - Sweat - Bile - Faeces - Urine

Disease processes
Disease Processes which affect liver and kidney function , the organs of medication elimination, are responsible for large variations in pharmacokinetics.
Medicine Classifications
ACE Inhibitors
medications that inhibit the activity of the angiotenzin converting enxyme, ACE, which causes blood vessels to dilate, resulting in lowered blood pressure. Examples of ACE Inhibitors include cilzapril, lisinopril, captopril, and quinapril
Alpha And Beta - adrenergic antagonists
Are medications that stimulate both alpha and beta receptors causing dilaton of bronchioles and constriction of blood vessels. Adrenaline is an example of this medication.

Remember, Alpha Receptors cause Contriction, and Beta Receptors cause Dilation

Analagesics Include NSAIDS And Opoids‚Ä¶
NSAIDS ( Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory Drugs)
are a group of anti- inflammatory medicines that are used to relieve pain, such as Ibuprofen and diclofenac.
Opoids
such as Morphine and fentanyl, bind to opiate receptor sites in the brain and spinal cord. They block the transmission of pain messages to the brain therefore reducing the feeeling of pain.
graph TD
  A[1. Painful Stimuli] -- Spinal Cord Takes message to the brain --> B[Brain]

AngioTensin 2 Blockers
Angiotensin 2 Blockers are medicines which block the action of the hormone angiotensin 2, resulting in decreased blood pressure. Angion tensin 2 Blockers prevent angiotensin 2 from binding to its receptors on the muscles surroung blood vessels. This results in vasodilation which reduces blood pressure. These blockers have similar effects to those of ACE Inhibitors and are commonly used when a patient can not tolerate an ACE Inhibitor. Examples of AngioTensin 2 Blockers include candesarten and Losartan.
Antibiotics
Used to treat bacterial infections, They Inhibit the growth of, or destroy, bacterial micro-organisms. They can be further classified..
Penicillin Based
Penicillin based Medications, Such As amoxicillin, are beta-lactam antibiotics which have a broad activity against many bacteria. Many Bacteria are resistant to amoxicillin due to their ability to produce the enxyme beta-lactamaze, which destroys the active part of beta-lactam antibiotics. Co-amoxiclav contains amoxicillin and claculanic acid. The clavulanic acid inhibits the beta-lactamaze enzymƒìso that the amoxicillin can effectively kill the bacteria.
Cephalosporions
Cephalosporins are a class of beta-lactam antibiotics. They have a broad activity agains bacteria and are less susceptible to the enxyme beta-lactamze. Cephalosporions are used for patients that have a severe allergy to penicillin antibiotics. An example is Ceftriaxone.
Anti-coagulants
medicines that interrupt the blood clotting process, and help prevent blood clots, such as Warfarin, and Heparin (Not Aspirin, which is an anti-platelet).
Antiemetics
medicines that are effective in the suppresssion of nausea and vomiting. Ondansetron is an anti-emetic.
Antihistamines
anatagonise (block) the action of histamine. Histamine is responsible for immediate hypersensitibity reactions such as itching and sneezing. Loratadine is an example of an antiHistamine.
Antiplatelets
Antiplatelet Medicines
Beta Blockers
are medications that block the effect of beta-adregeneric substances. They Stopy the heart rate increasing and limit the force which which the heart contracts which in turn reduces blood pressure. Names of these medicines comomnly end in ‚Äúlol‚Äù. Examples include Metroprolol, atenolol, bisoprolol, and sotalol.
Bronchodilators.
Cause dilation of the bronchioles. Examples of Bronchodilators are salbulatamol and Ipratropium. In the out- of hospital environment, bronchodilators are adminsitered for shortness of breath, caused by bronchospasm associated with asthma or COPD.
Calcium Channel Blockers
Calciumc Channel blockers relax and dilate the blood vessels by affecting muscle cells in the arterial walls, resulting in decreased blood pressure. Also Known as calcium channel antagonists, They are commonly used as anti-hypertensive medications, although some classes of calcium channel blockers slow the heart rate, which enables use as treatment for angina and atrial fibriliation. Examples of Calcium channel blockers include diltiazem, verapimil, amlodipine, and felodipine.
Corticosteroids
Inihibit the production of inflammatory mediators, resulting in a reduction in inflammatory responses. Prednsione is a corticosteroid
Diuretics
Diuretics increase the amount of water and salt eliminated from the body as urine. They are commonly used to treat a range of conditions, such as hypertension, heart failure, and oedema. There are several classes of diuretic, but the individual classes are not important. Examples of diuretics include frusemide, bendrofluazide, and spironolactone.
Oral Hypoglycaemics
Oral Hypoglycaemics reduce the amount of glucose in the bloodstream. There are different classifications of Oral Hypoglycaemics, and each classification works in a slightly different way to manage blood glucose levels. Some increase the amount of insulin created by the pancreas, some increase the sensitivity of taget organs to insulin, some reduce the production of glucose by the liver, and some decrease the rate that glucose is absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract. Examples of commonly found Oral hypgolycaemics include gliclazide, metformin, and glipizide.
Vasodilators
cause dilation of the blood vessels, increasing blood flow. Vasodilators are used to treat hypertension, angina, and heart failure. An example of this medication is GTN.
Review Questions
Recap Questions

What is Osmosis?
What is diffusion?
What is active transport?

Questions about Pharmacology


What is the difference between pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics?


Write out the Definitions we have learnt from this page.


Why do we do multiple dosing?


What are factors that influence biavailability?


Distribution is determined by:


What is the primary site of metabolism?


What is the first pass effect?


What are factors that influence metabolism?


What routes of elimination are there?


A medicine that produces a parasympathetic response is called ‚Ä¶ because‚Ä¶


A medicine that produces a sympathetic response is called ‚Ä¶ because‚Ä¶


What is the difference between Parental and Enteral Routes of Medication?


What effect does Shock Has on the Different Route‚Äôs Of Medication? Why?


How does Surface Area in the GI Tract Affect Absorption?


What does Lipoid Mean?
Relating to or resembling Fat.


Why do lipid soulble medications absorb more rapidly than non-lipid soluble medicaitons?


The PH of Blood Is‚Ä¶


The PH of Stomach Acid, COcaCola, Banana‚Äôs , Water, Baking Soda, and Ammonia is‚Ä¶

Stomach Acid: 1.5 (Acid)
Coca Cola: 2.7 (Acid)
Banana: 5 (Acid)
Water: 7 - Neutral
Blood: 7.5 (Alkaline)
Baking Soda: 8.4 (Alkaline)
Ammonia: 12 (Very Alkaline)



Where are the Majority of Medications Are Absorbed?
The Majority of Medications Are absorbed in the Intestines When Taken from the GI Tract?
Aspirin is one of the very few medications absorbed in the stomach. The Vast Majority Of Absorption occurs in the intestines.


Why are different medications either weak acids or bases, and how does this affect absorption?


The Higher the Medication Concentration, the higher the.. Absorption


D

Scuba Diving
Diving Pressures

























Atmospheric pressureBoyle‚Äôs Law of pressurethe pressure of a given mass of an ideal gas is  inversely proportional to its volume, when at a constant temperatureDalton‚Äôs Law of pressure/Henry‚Äôs Law of Pressure
Atmospheric pressure
sea level - 14.7 psi - one atmosphere of presure.
every 10 meters is the equivalent change of one atmosphere of pressure.

Gases are used quicker
gases become more compressed in the diver themselves - lungs, vest and mask.
gases become more soluble and readily absorbed.




as a diver ascends, higher amounts of absorbed gases need to be given time to disperse.

St-John.content:
Drugs
Conditions
Module 1
Module 2
Module 3
SOAP is a common medical documentation format used for patient assessments and progress notes. It stands for:

S ‚Äì Subjective (What the patient reports: symptoms, history)
O ‚Äì Objective (What you observe: vitals, exam findings, tests)
A ‚Äì Assessment (Your working diagnosis or differential)
P ‚Äì Plan (Next steps: treatment, investigations, follow-up)

Mnemonics and Tools


                  
                  Important
                  
                


Cervical Spine Clearance -
4 Criteria to be cleared:

No altered sensation
No mid-line or cervical spine tenderness on palpation
No distracting injury
No altered motor power

Needs a Collar When:

SEVERE tenderness /cervical spine pain (clinical judgement)
Clear symptoms of spinal cord injury
